properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and humid airmass will remain over New Brunswick today. Maximum temperatures near 30 degrees will persist over New Brunswick today, with lows tonight near 18 degrees providing little relief. Humidex values of 37 to 39 will also persist. Maximum temperatures along the Bay of Fundy, will be somewhat cooler. However, areas slightly inland are still likely to reach heat warning criteria. Temperatures will cool somewhat on Thursday as a trough of low pressure moves across the region. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T23:08:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-31T07:09:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3024185703.2019

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T20:37:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-31T08:37:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2783308963.2019

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wildfire smoke is causing poor air quality and locally reduced visibilities at times. ### Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors, and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk. People with lung diseases, such as asthma and COPD, can be particularly sensitive to air pollution. They will generally experience more serious health effects at lower levels. Pollution can aggravate their diseases, leading to increased medication use, doctor and emergency room visits, and hospital visits. For more information please visit Alberta Health Services at www.albertahealthservices.ca/news/air.aspx. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-08-01T02:25:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, Alberta Environment and Parks, Alberta Health, Alberta Health Services, 2019-07-31T10:26:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2039186000.2019

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and humid airmass will remain over Prince Edward Island today. Maximum temperatures are expected to reach 30 degrees again today. Overnight lows tonight are expected to fall to near 19 degrees providing little relief from the heat. Humidex values near 38 are expected again today. Temperatures across the island will cool somewhat on Thursday as a trough of low pressure moves in from the northwest. Daytime highs on Thursday are forecast to be around 24 degrees with humidex values near 30. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T23:10:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-31T07:11:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0621842793.2019

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Smoke may be causing poor air quality and reducing visibility. Poor air quality due to forest fire smoke is expected to improve this morning. ### Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk. If you, or someone in your care, develop symptoms, reduce strenuous outdoors activities where ever possible until the air quality improves. When outdoors, if your breathing becomes difficult or uncomfortable, stop or reduce strenuous physical activities. If you experience irritation of eyes, nose or throat, shortness of breath or other respiratory symptoms, you should take action to reduce your exposure to smoke. If you are feeling unwell and experiencing symptoms, contact your health care provider for advice. Issued jointly by Environment Canada and the Northwest Territories Departments of Environment and Natural Resources and Health and Social Services. For more information on air quality and your health, please visit the Northwest Territories Department of Health and Social Services at www.hss.gov.nt.ca/en/services/environmental-health/air-quality. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-07-31T19:59:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Northwest Territories Departments of Environment and Natural Resources and Health and Social Services, 2019-07-31T10:29:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1219377183.2019
Area: Wrigley Region, Norman Wells - Tulita Region, Fort Good Hope Region

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Patches of dense fog developed overnight in central Alberta, including along sections of Highway 16 and Highway 2. The fog will dissipate later this morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and humid airmass continues over Nova Scotia and will persist into Thursday. Daytime highs over inland areas of Nova Scotia are forecast to be near 30 degrees today with overnight lows near 18 degrees tonight providing little relief. Humidex values are expected to reach near 38 again today. Temperatures over northern parts of the province will begin to cool down on Thursday as a trough of low pressure moves in from the northwest. Elsewhere the warm and humid conditions will persist. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T23:09:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-31T07:10:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1866733113.2019

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Periods of torrential rainfall will produce scattered accumulations of 50 to 100 mm by Wednesday morning. A large area of rainfall with embedded thunderstorms will track through the Kamsack region early this morning. Rainfall will be torrential at times with numerous thunderstorms moving through the region. Widespread rainfall accumulations of 20 to 30 mm are expected with localized accumulations of 50 to 100 mm in areas that receive numerous thunderstorms through the early morning hours. The rain will taper off from west to east between 5 AM and 8 AM CST. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T19:00:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-31T09:52:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0591105205.2019

properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. An area of fog has moved over Sachs Harbour from the Beaufort sea. Expect fog to persist through the morning before clearing after noon. ### Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and torrential rain. The potential for severe thunderstorms will continue this morning over portions of western Manitoba. An area of rain and thunderstorms developed in eastern Saskatchewan overnight and is tracking across the Parklands area of Manitoba this morning. The main threats from these thunderstorms will be large hail, heavy downpours and strong winds. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T16:59:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-31T13:06:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3688419930.2019

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and torrential rain. The potential for severe thunderstorms will continue this morning over portions of eastern Saskatchewan and western Manitoba. An area of rain and thunderstorms has developed in eastern Saskatchewan overnight. It will continue to move into Manitoba this morning bringing a primary threat of torrential rainfall and a risk of large hail. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
